“The Age of Love” (Spanish: La edad del amor) is an Argentine musical comedy by Julio Saraceni with the famous actress and singer Lolita Torres in the title role. Many years ago, the young aristocrat Alberto was going to marry the famous singer Soledad, but his father, who is also called Alberto, upset the wedding, considering the marriage of a lawyer and an actress to be a misalliance.
A quiet and shy girl Katya is assigned to the construction of a highway, having the profession of a driver. The young workers welcome the young trainee very warmly and help her with everything.

Twelfth Night, or What You Will, often simply Twelfth Night, is a play, a five-act romantic comedy by William Shakespeare, named after the twelfth night festival of the Christmas season, from December 25 to January 5, and written around 1601–1602 as entertainment for the Christmas season. The plot centers on twins Viola and Sebastian, separated in a shipwreck.

Shadow at the Pier is a Soviet feature film shot by director Mikhail Vinyarsky at the Odessa Film Studio in 1955 based on the novel “On the Ocean” by Soviet writer Nikolai Panov. About how in one southern port city, Soviet counterintelligence officers, with the help of our sailors and ordinary citizens, exposed the machinations of enemy spies and saboteurs aimed at destroying a floating dock.

The talented shipbuilder Yuri Ershov was overtaken by misfortune - after an accident, his legs were paralyzed and he was chained to his bed. But Ershov does not give up, he continues to live and work actively.
“Dangerous Paths” is an adventure film directed by Alexander Alekseev and Evgeny Alekseev. Released on February 3, 1955, the box office leader (9th place) - 29.
“Footprints in the Snow” is a Soviet detective feature film, filmed in 1955 by director Adolf Bergunker based on the story of the same name by Georgy Bryantsev.

Young blacksmith Ilya Gromov from the White Keys collective farm wins the title of regional champion in wrestling among collective farmers. Seeing his success, the authorities decide to transfer him to the city.

“Dzhigit Girl” is a Soviet comedy musical feature film, shot by director Pavel Bogolyubov in 1955 at the Alma-Ata Film Studio - the first Kazakh color comedy film. Aidar and Galia have been in love with each other for a long time.

The modern bridge was opened in 1945 on the site of the bridge of the same name built in 1817, named in honor of the victory in the Battle of Waterloo. The Waterloo Girder Bridge is grey, similar in design to the London Bridge built in 1973, but the Waterloo has 4 pillars while the London Bridge has two.

“The Red and the Black” (French: Le Rouge et le Noir) (subtitle: Chronicle of the 19th century (French: Chronique du XIXe siècle) is a novel by the French writer Stendhal (1783-1842), published in 1830. The action of the work takes place in the 1820s in France.

“Heroes of Shipka” is a 1954 Soviet-Bulgarian film dedicated to the events of the Russian-Turkish War of 1877-1878 and the liberation of the Bulgarians from the Ottoman yoke. The Balkan Peninsula is under the heel of the Ottoman Empire.

The story chronicles journalist Georges Duroy's corrupt rise to power from a poor former cavalry NCO in France's African colonies, to one of the most successful men in Paris, most of which he achieves by manipulating a series of powerful, intelligent, and wealthy women.

“The Jumper” is a short story by Anton Chekhov, written in November 1891. According to researchers, the work is based on a true story, but the story itself is “broader than the real situation reflected in the plot.

Boris Fedorovich Godunov (monastic name Bogolep; August 2, 1552 - April 13, 1605) - boyar, brother-in-law of Tsar Fedor I Ivanovich, in 1585-1598 the de facto ruler of the Russian kingdom, from February 17 (27), 1598 to April 13 (23), 1605 - the first Russian Tsar from the Godunov dynasty. Boris Godunov began his career by serving at the court of Ivan the Terrible.

“Romeo and Juliet” (English: Romeo and Juliet) is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, telling about the love of a young man and a girl from two warring Verona families - the Montagues and the Capulets. The work is usually dated to 1594-1595.

“Carnival Night” is a 1956 Soviet comedy musical film directed by Eldar Ryazanov. This is his first independent feature film released on the big screen, and the third role of Lyudmila Gurchenko.

Mister 420 (Hindi श्री ४२०, Shree 420) is an Indian black and white romantic drama film directed by Raj Kapoor, released on September 6, 1955. The film consists of two parts, the first of which contains elements of burlesque and pure comedy.

“Case No. 306” is a Soviet one-part feature film, shot in 1956 by director Anatoly Rybakov based on the story of the same name by Matvey Roizman. Leader of Soviet film distribution (1956, second place) - 33.5 million viewers.
“Two Captains” is an adventure novel by writer Veniamin Kaverin, which he wrote in 1938-1944. The novel went through more than a hundred reprints.
“The Rumyantsev Case” is a Soviet full-length color feature film produced at the Lenfilm Studio in 1955 by director Joseph Kheifitz. It is one of the first Soviet films of the detective genre.

Having met by chance, Anna and Andrea get engaged and spend a lot of time together: a chaste Sunday walk, an exchange of letters, a plan to get married as soon as possible. Meanwhile, Anna is looking for a job so she can save up for a dowry, but her beauty is an obstacle to finding a job.
“Different Fates” is a Soviet feature-length color film filmed by director Leonid Lukov in 1956 at the Gorky Film Studio. Young Leningraders, yesterday's schoolchildren, are entering adulthood.
“Spring on Zarechnaya Street” is a Soviet feature film filmed in 1956 by directors Felix Mironer and Marlen Martynovich Khutsiev. One of the most popular films of the 1950s, it attracted 30.

“The Immortal Garrison” is a feature film about the defenders of the Brest Fortress, filmed in 1956 by directors Zakhar Agranenko and Eduard Tisse based on a script by Konstantin Simonov. The film is dedicated to the defense of the Brest Fortress in the first days of the war.

In many pre-industrial societies and some modern countries with agrarian economies, sons rather than daughters were and still are important because men have higher social status there, as men are physically stronger and perform the tasks of agriculture more efficiently. In China, in order to eliminate rapid population growth, the “One Child Policy” was in effect.

“Volnitsa” is a Soviet color feature film, shot in 1955 by director Grigory Roshal at the Mosfilm studio based on the story of the same name by Soviet writer F. Gladkov, part of his autobiographical trilogy.

Maxim Perepelitsa is a cheerful and resourceful guy from a Ukrainian village, a well-known personality in his native village. He has a fantastic ability to come up with all sorts of tall tales and shirk work.

“Captain of the Old Turtle” is a Soviet historical adventure feature film directed by Vsevolod Voronin and Genrikh Gabay, based on the story of the same name by Lev Linkov at the Odessa Film Studio in 1956. The film tells about the fight against the counter-revolutionary underground in the south of the country in the first years of Soviet power, about the service of the first Soviet border guards, the Black Sea, who in the early 1920s had the opportunity to intercept scows with foreign cargo for hidden anti-Soviet fighters.

Shortly after the end of World War II, in the small French town of Cibourg, a policeman responding to shots fired finds a woman with three bullet wounds in house 26 on Rue Dante. The victim turns out to be the famous actress Madeleine Thibault; In the hospital, she regains consciousness and tells the investigator her story.

“A Man is Born” is a Soviet feature film, melodrama directed by Vasily Ordynsky based on the script by Leonid Agranovich. A young girl, Nadezhda Smirnova, comes to Moscow to go to college, but fails the exam.

Since the 19th century, the tradition of a post-wedding journey has emerged in Russian secular society, during which the newlyweds celebrated their wedding. In a figurative sense - the initial time of any joint venture, a business when nothing yet causes worries (jokingly).
“The Fate of the Drummer” is a story by Arkady Gaidar for middle school age, written in 1938. Published in 1939, it immediately gained enormous popularity among Soviet youth.
There is an aviation base located not far from the border. Its main tasks are to provide assistance to border guards and protect forests from fires and other natural disasters.
“The Forty-First” is a feature film directed by Grigory Chukhrai, based on the story of the same name by Boris Lavrenev. The second film adaptation of the story after the film by Yakov Protazanov.

A garment factory operates on a continuous basis and also produces defective products, delivering them to a department store. The head of the ready-to-wear section in a department store, Mikhail Ivanovich Krylov, comes into conflict with the director of the clothing factory, Anna Andreevna Andreeva.

“Alien Relatives” is a Soviet full-length black-and-white feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1955 by director Mikhail Schweitzer based on the story “Not for the Court” by V. The plot is based on the conflict between Komsomol member, leading collective farmer Fedor and the parents of his young wife, ardent opponents of collective farm life.

The new chairman of the collective farm, Semyon Frolov, who previously lived here, arrives in the village of Krutiye Gorki. Taking over business from former chairman Gorelov, he discovers the illegal sale of hay.

The plot contained all the makings of an ordinary “production” film with a cliched conflict in those years: the boss is a conservative, his subordinate is an innovator. But the authors did not follow a literary scheme, but rather life itself, and this saved the film.

“The Tragedy of Othello, The Moor of Venice” or briefly “Othello” (eng. The Tragedy of Othello, The Moor of Venice) is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, written around 1603 based on the novella “The Moor of Venice” by Cinzio Giraldi from the collection “Ecatommiti”.
“Sailor Chizhik” is a Soviet drama film filmed at the Kyiv Film Studio in 1955. Director and scriptwriter - Vladimir Brown.

A young worker at an automobile manufacturing plant, Anton Karnilin, fails to fulfill the production plan due to love troubles with the daughter of the plant manager, Lyusya, quarrels with friends, and starts drinking. The foreman and his adopted daughter Tatyana Olenina, a design engineer at the plant, come to his aid.

Ilya Muromets (full epic name is Ilya Muromets son Ivanovich, there are also variants: Ilya Morovlin, Muravlenin, Murovets, Muromlyan; Ilya the Serpent Fighter) is one of the main characters of the ancient Russian and Russian epic epic. Bogatyr, a peasant son, a native of North-Eastern Rus', who came to serve in Kyiv with Prince Vladimir; led the defense of Ancient Rus'.

Mexicans (Spanish: Mexicanos) are the third largest nation (after the US Americans and Brazilians) in the Western Hemisphere. Mexicans have diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds, but they share a common Latin American background, namely Mexican culture and the Spanish language.

A powerful underwater explosion occurred in Soviet territorial waters of the Pacific Ocean. An employee of the Oceanographic Institute, Denisov, a casual witness to this explosion, notices the unusually rapid growth of lichen on the coastal rocks.

MTS sends a young combine operator Nikolai Vorobtsov to harvest grain at the advanced collective farm “Luch”. But his work did not go well, and the collective farmers, except for Nastya, who fell in love with him, began to make fun of him in ditties.

“They Were the First” is a Soviet full-length black and white feature film produced at the Moscow Gorky Film Studio in 1956 by director Yuri Egorov. The film's script is based on the play "On Happy Street" by Jozef Princev.
“Walking through Torment” is a trilogy of novels by A. Tolstoy, tracing the fate of the Russian intelligentsia on the eve, during and after the revolutionary events of 1917.
“Quiet Don” is an epic novel in four volumes written by Mikhail Sholokhov (1905-1984). Volumes 1–3 were written from 1925 to 1932, published in the magazine “October” in 1928–1932.

“Old Man Hottabych” is a Soviet story-fairy tale by Lazar Lagin about the adventures of the pioneer Volka Kostylkov, who discovered a jug with a genie named Hassan Abdurrahman ibn Hottab who had been sitting in it for three and a half thousand years. Grateful to his savior, Hottabych begins to serve him, performing all sorts of miracles, and over time, Volka re-educates Hottabych into a Soviet citizen.
“Night Patrol” is a Soviet feature film filmed in 1957 by director Vladimir Sukhobokov. The Soviet actor and singer Mark Bernes starred in one of the main roles.

A film about the unknown heroes of the Great Patriotic War and the struggle of internationalists against fascism. In 1942, Alexey Severin, an officer of the Red Army who was wounded in battle, using the documents of the dying Miroslav, a Czech doctor serving in the German army, avoids capture and, using his certificate, ends up in Slovakia.
Fanfan la Tulipe is a 1952 French comedy adventure film directed by Christian-Jaque. It has also been categorized under swashbuckler films.

“The Secret of Two Oceans” is a science fiction novel by Grigory Adamov. The novel describes the voyage of the Soviet submarine "Pioneer" from Leningrad to Vladivostok through the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.

A splinter (also splinter, splinter, foreign body) is a fragment of a larger object (usually wood) or a foreign body that penetrates or is deliberately introduced into the body, accompanied by a wound. The foreign body must be inside the tissue to be considered a splinter.

“The House Where I Live” is a Soviet feature film filmed at the Moscow Gorky Feature Film Studio in 1957 by directors Lev Kulidzhanov and Yakov Segel. 1935 Two families move into a new house on the outskirts of Moscow, a communal apartment: the Davydovs with three children and newlyweds Dmitry and Lida Kashirin.

“The Cranes Are Flying” is a 1957 Soviet black-and-white feature film directed by Mikhail Kalatozov, based on the play “Forever Living” by Viktor Rozov. Winner of the Palme d'Or at the 1958 Cannes International Film Festival.

Born in Volzhana, raised by a stern and domineering grandmother, Ekaterina was left without a mother at an early age. Rare meetings with her father, an old, honored captain, formed a strong character in her.

A sociable young mechanic moves into a vacant room in a communal apartment and immediately wins the sympathy of the residents. Madame Shpakovskaya, the mother of her only daughter, has her own ideas for a prosperous young man, in whom she recognizes a “celebrity.
The era of the Civil War in Russia: “Yudenich near Petrograd, Denikin nearby” (1919). A strange soldier (Vladimir Kenigson) appears on the train and protects a girl (Margarita Volodina) from robbers.

My Poor Beloved Mother (Spanish: Pobre mi madre querida) is a 1948 Argentine melodrama film of the classical era of Argentine cinema, directed by Homero Manzi and Ralph Pappier and starring Hugo del Carril, Emma Gramatica, and Aída Luz. It was based on a tango of the same name by Pascual Contursi and José Betinotti.

“Pavel Korchagin” is a Soviet color feature film based on Nikolai Ostrovsky’s book “How the Steel Was Tempered,” filmed in 1956, the second film adaptation of this novel. The film takes place in 1920-1930.

“The Tale of First Love” is a Soviet feature film based on the story of the same name by Nikolai Atarov. The film premiered on July 28, 1957 during the VI World Festival of Youth and Students.
Anna and Evgeniy love each other and decide to get married. Anna talks to her mother for a long time.

“A Woman’s Fate” is a 1957 Soviet film filmed at the Georgia-Film studio by director Nikoloz Sanishvili based on the novel of the same name by Mikheil Javakhishvili. The film ranks 23rd on the list of USSR film distribution leaders in 1958; the film was watched by 22.
“The Fighter and the Clown” is a Soviet color feature film filmed at the Mosfilm studio in 1957. Director Konstantin Yudin began working on the film.

“An Extraordinary Summer” is a Soviet film directed by Vladimir Basov, a film adaptation of the novel of the same name by Konstantin Fedin. The second part of the film dilogy, begun in the film “First Joys” (1956).

“She Loves You” is a Soviet full-length color feature film produced at the Lenfilm Film Studio in 1956 by directors Semyon Derevyansky and Rafail Suslovich. All the magnificent heroes - tall, eloquent, with a fiery gaze - were snapped up by other authors for other paintings.

“Poddubensky Ditties” is a 1957 Soviet comedy feature film-play, filmed by director Herbert Rappoport at the Lenfilm film studio. Screen adaptation of the story by Sergei Antonov “Poddubensky ditties.
Khanka (Chinese: 兴凯湖 - Shinkaihu; also outdated: Shinkai or Hinkai) is a freshwater lake in the center of the Khanka lowland (plain). Belongs to the Amur drainage basin.

“Hostile Whirlwinds” (another name is “Felix Dzerzhinsky”) is a 1953 Soviet feature film. The film is named after the first words of the Russian revolutionary song “Varshavyanka” (“Hostile whirlwinds are blowing over us…”, translation by Krzhizhanovsky).

Petya, an eight-year-old orphan, is given “to be trained” by the German acrobat Karl Becker, who, with abuse and beatings, introduces his new assistant to the circus profession and mercilessly exploits the child in his performances. The only consolation that brightened up the harsh life of the “gutta-percha boy,” as Petya was called on the posters, was the care of the carpet clown Edwards (one of the best roles of Alexei Gribov), who took pity on the orphan and secretly taught him real circus art.

Commonly cultivated ornamental plants, colloquially called "mallows", usually belong to the genus Alcea, another genus of the same family. Mallow, from the Latin malva, (-ae), a term used in ancient Rome to designate various types of mallow, mainly the common mallow (Malva sylvestris), but also the marshmallow (Althaea officinalis) and the tree mallow (Malva arborea).

“Trubachev’s Detachment is Fighting” is a feature film directed by Ilya Frez, filmed in 1957 at the Gorky Film Studio based on the 2nd book of Valentina Oseeva’s novel “Vasyok Trubachev and His Comrades.” A continuation of the film “Vasyok Trubachev and His Comrades,” filmed two years earlier, which describes the adventures that befell the pioneers who found themselves in German-occupied territory during the Great Patriotic War and began to fight their enemies.

“Above Tissa” is a Soviet action-packed feature film produced in 1958 by director Dmitry Vasiliev based on the story of the same name by Alexander Avdeenko. Leader of the USSR film distribution in 1958 (45.

“A Girl with No Address” is a Soviet color feature film produced at the Mosfilm studio in 1957 by director Eldar Ryazanov with Svetlana Karpinskaya in the title role. The “ancestor” of the film thematically is the film “A Girl with Character” (1939), shot by director Konstantin Yudin with actress Valentina Serova.

“The Street is Full of Surprises” is a Soviet feature-length color film filmed by director Sergei Sidelev at the Lenfilm studio in 1957. Chief accountant Porfiry Petrovich Smirnov-Alyansky, who had a good time at the anniversary of his colleague, cashier Ivan Zakharovich Vodnev, climbs into the traffic controller’s booth at night and disrupts traffic on one of the streets of Leningrad, but the arriving guard Vasily Shaneshkin mistakenly delivers to the police station not the escaped violator, but the completely decent cashier Vodnev.

“The Case of the Motleys” is a Soviet detective feature film, shot in 1958 by director Nikolai Dostal at the Mosfilm film studio based on the story of the same name by Arkady Adamov. It is the director's last completed work.
“Red Leaves” is a Soviet feature film directed by Vladimir Korsh-Sablin, filmed at the Belarusfilm film studio in 1958. The film premiered on December 8, 1958.

A sailor from a southern town, Sergei Chaikin, whose songs are loved and known by sailors, is in love with student and athlete Lena. But it’s not only shyness that prevents Sergei from explaining himself to the mocking girl.

A date (or a romantic date) is a pre-arranged meeting between two lovers; in general, a meeting of two people looking for acquaintance, mutual relationships. In its most general sense, it is a meeting of two people building a relationship and exploring whether they are compatible to spend time together as a couple.

“My Dear Man” is a Soviet color film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1958 by director Joseph Kheifits based on the novel by Yuri German “The Cause You Serve” with the use of plot material, which was later embodied in the novels “My Dear Man” and “I am Responsible for Everything. ” Doctor Vladimir Ustimenko is a man of duty and honor, devoted to the work he serves, and to the one and only love that he carries throughout his life: love for Varvara Stepanova, an eccentric girl who dreamed of becoming a great actress, but ended up becoming a geologist.
“Girl with a Guitar” is a Soviet feature film filmed by director Alexander Faintzimmer at the Mosfilm studio in 1958. Script writers: Boris Laskin, Vladimir Polyakov.
“Difficult Happiness” is a Soviet feature film directed by Alexander Stolper, filmed in 1958. The premiere took place on October 27, 1958.

“The Idiot” (“Nastasya Filippovna”) is a Soviet feature film based on the first part of the novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky, filmed by Ivan Pyryev in 1958 and designated in the credits as “part one. ” The script was written by the director ten years before the start of filming➤.
Traffic controller Tarapunka met Galya during the Great Patriotic War. He told his only friend Shtepsel about his love for a sweet girl with a rare and unusual surname - Turmoil.

“A Groom for Laura” (Spanish: Un novio para Laura) is an Argentine musical comedy by Julio Saraceni with the famous actress and singer Lolita Torres in the title role. The film was shot in black and white, but the final scene, where Lolita Torres sings the song Despierta mi amor, was shot in color (the color was lost in some copies).

“It Happened in Penkov” is a Soviet full-length black-and-white feature film produced at the Gorky Film Studio in 1957 by director Stanislav Rostotsky based on the story by Sergei Antonov. A young livestock specialist, Tonya Glechikova, is assigned to the collective farm.

Mamluks (also Mamluks, Arabic: مملوك‎ mamluk - “owned”, “slave”, plural مماليك‎ mamelik, from Arabic: مَلِك‎ malik - “owner”) - a military class in medieval Egypt, originally recruited from young slaves of Turkic origin from the Eurasian steppe (mainly Cumans), but then the institution of military slavery quickly spread to representatives of the peoples of the Caucasus (Circassians, Abkhazians, Georgians and Armenians converted to Islam), residents of the Balkans (Albanians, Greeks and others), as well as the southern Slavs and Ruthenians (see Sakaliba). The Mamluks were also recruited from the Egyptians.

“On the Distant Shores” (Azerbaijani: Uzaq sahillərdə) is a 1958 Soviet film based on the story of the same name by Hasan Seyidbeyli and Imran Kasumov “On the Distant Shores”. The film is based on the story of the same name by Hasan Seyidbeyli and Imran Kasumov “On Distant Shores”.

Volunteer (volunteers) - a person (persons) who carries out any activity voluntarily, and often free of charge, without receiving material remuneration for it.
“Incident at Mine Eight” is a Soviet feature film directed by Vladimir Basov from a script by Valery Frid and Yuli Dunsky in 1957. The film premiered on January 14, 1958.

A little-known German musical film, the plot of which was a remake of the 1935 French film Fanfare of Love, and the same plot was used as the basis, significantly changed, for the now world famous American film Some Like It Hot from 1959, whose director Billy Wilder called the German film: “a very low-budget, very third-rate German picture. ” In 1953, a sequel to the German film “Fanfare of Marriage” was released (neither the French nor the Americans have an analogue); the sequel was shot by a different director, according to the original script, but with the same actors in the lead roles.
“Knock on Any Door” is a Soviet feature film about the work of a police officer with troubled teenagers. The premiere took place on September 7, 1958.

A talented craftsman Andrei Panchenko has been appointed head of a large mine. He is full of hope and happy, because next to him is his beloved, charming and reliable Tamara.
Experienced military pilot Alexey Kostrov dreams of testing new jet aircraft. He leaves to work at a steppe airfield, where he encounters difficulties and dangers.

A Quiet Home (Hungarian: Csendes otthomn) is also a 1958 Hungarian comedy film directed by Frigyes Bán and starring Ferenc Zenthe, Erzsi Galambos and Irén Psota. It was shot at the Hunnia Studios in Budapest.

Gold crowns or Gold teeth, metal crowns coated with titanium nitride - shiny yellow dental crowns, at the beginning of the 20th century it was mainly gold and its alloys, and since the mid-20th century mainly metal crowns with a coating similar to gold, most often titanium nitride, these are the cheapest and most durable crowns available to people with low incomes as a way to stay with their teeth without aesthetically pleasing in appearance, they can last 15 years or more, which is why they were installed en masse in the USSR and are still installed in the CIS, they require minimal grinding of teeth. Also in the USSR they installed crowns made of tombak, an alloy of copper and zinc, which also look like gold.
The title of the film is borrowed from the collection of stories by O. Henry “Business People” (English: Strictly Business; 1910) and the story of the same name that opens this collection.

“Empty Flight” is a Soviet black and white feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1962 by director Vladimir Vengerov. The picture was created based on the plot of the story of the same name by Sergei Antonov.

The story takes place during the Mexican Revolution. After Juana Gallo's (Maria Felix) father and boyfriend are executed by the government officials, Juana takes a courageous response in the face of her loss and rescues the men from the village who were taken as prisoners.

“It Happened at the Police” is a 1963 Soviet black-and-white feature film about the work of the police, based on the story “Seabiscuit” by Israel Metter. “The Big Road” is a Soviet-Czechoslovak feature film directed by Yuri Ozerov, filmed in 1962 at the Mosfilm film studio with the participation of the Barrandov studio. The script is based on a literary version of the biography of the Czech writer Jaroslav Hasek.

Apple of discord (ancient Greek: μῆλον ἀέθλιον), or apple of Eris (ancient Greek: τὸ τῆς Ἔριδος μῆλον), - in ancient Greek myths, a golden apple, on which was written “most beautiful” (ancient Greek τῇ καλλίστῃ), thrown by the goddess of discord Eris on the banquet table during the wedding of Peleus and Thetis. “On demand” is a special form of postal address, according to which the postal item is stored at the post office of the destination for a certain time (usually up to 30 days) until it is claimed by the addressee. This postal service can be useful if the recipient does not want to receive notifications or does not have his own post office box or address, as well as if he is staying at the destination temporarily or does not trust the partners with whom he has postal connections.

"Gaudeamus igitur" (Latin for "So let us rejoice") or just "Gaudeamus", also known as "De brevitate vitae" ("On the Shortness of Life"), is a popular academic commercium song in many European countries, mainly sung or performed at university graduation ceremonies. Back of the Medal is a 1965 Croatian film directed by Fadil Hadžić, starring Toma Jovanović, Franjo Kumer, Rade Marković and Judita Han. Eva Ružić (Judita Han) is sentenced to seven years in prison for embezzlement, after fully admitting her guilt in court.

About the creation during the Civil War of a national Uzbek theater for the entire people by the efforts of two dreamers - the young Uzbek playwright Muzaffar and the first actress of the Uzbek theater - a Russian girl from a family of Old Believers Natasha - in Uzbek "Natasha Khanum". Attempted crime is the actions of a person directly aimed at committing a crime, but not completed due to circumstances beyond the control of this person. In most criminal legal systems of the world, an attempt to commit a crime, in accordance with the views of the classical school of criminal law, is interpreted as the beginning of the execution of a crime.

King Thrushbeard (German: König Drosselbart) is a romantic fairy tale-short story from the first collection of “Children's and Household Tales” (Kinder- und Hausmärchen) by the Brothers Grimm (first edition 1812/1815) number 52. “We, the Russian People” is a 1965 Soviet two-part film directed by Vera Stroeva based on the film-novel of the same name by Vsevolod Vishnevsky about the events that took place in a separate regiment of the Russian Imperial Army in 1917. Sergei Eisenstein wanted to direct a film epic based on the novel published in 1937, Efim Dzigan began developing the script, but work was stopped by the management of Mosfilm in 1938. Having recreated in the novel-film “We, the Russian People” the history of the Petrovsky regiment from the end of 1916 to the beginning of 1918, Vishnevsky seemed to show the history of the Russian people, who went through a difficult path from the imperialist war to the civil war, from lawlessness and oppression to revolution and freedom

Summary Contents Subject index In a unique comparative ethnography of two family therapy programs, Gubrium deftly shows how differing organizational perceptions make visible the social construction of domestic disorder. Contrasting images of home life—one viewing domestic order as a system of authority, the other as a configuration of emotional bonds—serve to highlight different senses of the family as being out of control and to recommend alternate forms of intervention.

Stepmother is a stepmother, a woman in the family, the wife of her husband in relation to his children from a previous marriage (for a man, a similar term is the term “stepfather”). In relation to the stepmother, stepchildren are called “stepson” (“stepsons”) or “stepdaughter” (“stepdaughters”).

Zemlya Sannikov (Sannikova Zemlya) is a “ghost island” located north of the New Siberian Islands in the Arctic Ocean, which was allegedly seen by some researchers in the 19th century, including Yakov Sannikov. “Return of the Violin” (Azerbaijani: Skripkanın sərgüzəşti) is a Soviet adventure military action film with elements of a 1972 children’s film produced by the Azerbaijanfilm film studio. The events in the film take place in Odessa during the Great Patriotic War.

The Copper Tower is a film drama directed by Martin Hollé from 1970 based on Ivan Bukovčan's story about the friendship of a group of climbers Pirin, Starac and Valér in the High Tatras. This film is considered one of the gems of Slovak cinematography.

Cipollino (Italian: Cipollino) is an onion boy, the hero of the fairy-tale story “The Adventures of Cipollino” by the Italian writer Gianni Rodari, as well as performances and animated films based on Rodari’s book. In the Soviet Union, he was a member of the Merry Men Club.

Joe Hill is a 1971 biopic about the Swedish-American labor activist and songwriter Joe Hill, born Joel Emanuel Hägglund in Gävle, Sweden. It was directed by Swedish director Bo Widerberg and is a dramatization of Hill's life, depicting Hill's arrival as a poor immigrant in New York in 1902, his involvement with the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW), and his trial for murder, during which he defended himself.

Mackenna's Gold is a 1969 American feature film starring Gregory Peck, Omar Sharif, Telly Savalas, Ted Cassidy, Julie Newmar and Camilla Sparve, based on the novel of the same name by writer Will Henry. The novel is based on the legend of Adams' Lost Gold.

“Kalina Krasnaya” is a 1973 Soviet full-length color dramatic feature film by director and screenwriter Vasily Shukshin, based on his story of the same name at the Mosfilm film studio. Shukshin's last directorial work (he died six months after the film's release).

name_original: Unbelievable Adventures of Italians in Russia
web_summary: “The Incredible Adventures of Italians in Russia” (Italian: Una matta, matta, matta corsa in Russia - “One crazy, crazy, crazy race across Russia”) is a joint Soviet-Italian adventure comedy film, filmed in 1973 by director Eldar Ryazanov at the Mosfilm film studio. A ninety-two-year-old woman, who turns out to be a Russian emigrant, is taken to one of the Roman hospitals.

“Only “old men” go into battle” is a 1973 Soviet black-and-white feature film directed by Leonid Bykov, which tells about the everyday life of fighter pilots during the Great Patriotic War. Released in 1974, the film attracted 44.

The film shows the events on the Don during the Great Patriotic War and after it, taking place over almost twenty years. At the center of the film is the love story of a courageous and strong woman, integral in her directness, Antonina Kashirina, to the officer Nikitin, whom she saved during the war.

Apache (English Apache; self-name: Nde, Inde, Tinde, Tinneh - “people”) is a collective name for several culturally related tribes of North American Indians speaking the Apache languages ​​of the Athabaskan branch of the Na-Dene family. According to one version, the name Apache comes from the Yavapai epache (“man”); according to another, from apachu (“enemy”) in the Zuni language, who called the Navajo (diné).

Treasure of Silver Lake (German: Der Schatz im Silbersee) is a 1962 Western film directed by Harald Reinl, loosely based on German author Karl May's 1891 novel of the same name. It was the first in a highly-successful series of films based on May's works by the West German studios Rialto and Constantin Film, starring American actor Lex Barker as the frontiersman Old Shatterhand and French actor Pierre Brice as the Apache warrior Winnetou.
Sergey and Tatyana love each other very much. Sergei is conscripted into the army (marine corps), and Tatyana is waiting for his return.

“Remember Your Name” (Polish: Zapamiętaj imię swoje) is a Soviet-Polish full-length military drama feature film directed by Sergei Kolosov, filmed in 1974 jointly by the film studios “Mosfilm” (USSR) and “Illusion” (Poland). In Polish distribution, the film was shown with subtitles; the speech of the Polish actors was not drowned out by the translator's voice.

A trap (Turkic kapkan) is a device for catching animals, consisting of one or more springs, arcs (claws) that capture the neck or paw of the animal and a plate that activates the trap when pressed. Parade (French parade, Spanish parada, from Latin parāre ‘to prepare’), military parade or naval parade - the passage of troops in a solemn march with or without military equipment, it is also the formation of personnel or equipment on significant dates. A military parade is held, as a rule, on official holidays, celebrations of state and military significance, after the completion of major military exercises, as well as during the funeral of military personnel, leaders of the state or country, and other persons at whose burial military honors are required.

Heavy water - This term is usually used to refer to heavy hydrogen water, also known as deuterium oxide. Hydrogen heavy water has the same chemical formula as ordinary water, but instead of two atoms of the usual light isotope of hydrogen (protium), it contains two atoms of the heavy isotope of hydrogen - deuterium, and its oxygen is similar in isotopic composition to air oxygen.

A tropical cyclone is a type of cyclone, or low-pressure weather system, that occurs over a warm sea surface and is accompanied by severe thunderstorms, heavy rainfall, and gale-force winds. Tropical cyclones get their energy by raising moist air, condensing water vapor in the form of rain, and sending the drier air that is produced in this process down.

Amnesty (Greek αμνηστια - oblivion, forgiveness) is a measure applied by decision of a government authority to persons who have committed crimes, the essence of which is complete or partial release from punishment, replacement of punishment with a more lenient one, or termination of criminal prosecution. The Golden Fleece is in ancient Greek mythology the golden skin of a ram sent by the goddess of the clouds Nephele, or Hermes on the orders of Hera, or Zeus himself, on whose back the children of the Orkhomen king Athamas - Phrixus and Gella - went to the shores of Asia, fleeing the persecution of their stepmother Ino (or, according to another version of the myth, aunt Biadica). Meteor shower (starfall, star shower, English meteor shower) is a collection of meteors generated by the invasion of the Earth’s atmosphere by a swarm of meteoric bodies. Since meteor swarms occupy clearly defined orbits in outer space, then, firstly, meteor showers are observed at a strictly defined time of year, when the Earth passes the point of intersection of the orbits of the Earth and the swarm, and secondly, the radiants of the streams end up at a strictly defined point in the sky.

The Timok Rebellion (Serbian Cyrillic: Timočka buna, romanized: Timočka buna) was a popular uprising that began in eastern Serbia (now the region of the Timok Valley) on 28 September 1883, led by the People's Radical Party. It has been called the most important event in Serbia between independence (1878) and the First Balkan War (1912).

Rebetiko (Greek: ρεμπέτικο, pronounced ), plural rebetika (ρεμπέτικα ), occasionally transliterated as rembetiko or rebetico, is a term used to designate previously disparate kinds of urban Greek music which in the 1930s went through a process of musical syncretism and developed into a more distinctive musical genre. Twilight is the time interval during which the Sun is below the horizon, and natural illumination on Earth is provided by the scattering of sunlight in the atmosphere and the residual luminescent glow of the atmosphere itself caused by ionizing radiation from the Sun. Anemia (Greek αναιμία; from the Greek αν - a prefix meaning negation and the Greek αἷμα - blood), synonym - anemia, is a pathological clinical and hematological syndrome, which is accompanied by a decrease in the content of hemoglobin and red blood cells in the circulating blood and is characterized by impaired oxygen transport and the development of hypoxia. The word “anemia” without specification does not define a specific disease, since anemia is considered one of the symptoms of various pathological conditions of the body.

name_original: Once Upon a Time in America
web_summary: “Once Upon a Time in America” (English: Once Upon a Time in America, Italian: C'era una volta in America) is a gangster film directed by Sergio Leone, released in 1984 and partially based on the autobiographical work of Harry Gray. Shock (from the French choc - blow, push) is a pathological process that develops in response to the influence of extreme stimuli and is accompanied by a progressive disruption of the vital functions of the nervous, respiratory systems, circulatory system, metabolism and some other functions, the pathomechanism of which is based on a violation of hemodynamics, primarily microcirculation, with the development of tissue hypoxia. In essence, this is a breakdown of neurohumoral regulation and compensatory reactions of the body in response to extreme damage, with a further critical deterioration of the adaptation syndrome under stress.

Walking people, also called zahrebetniki or podsusedniki - in Russia of the 16th-18th centuries, a category of the population consisting of free people, not assigned to either the servicemen or the townspeople; These were servants released by their masters, people from captivity and generally not recorded in the scribe and census books. In the Russian state, only free walking people were completely free, not being bound by any social and state duties, they enjoyed complete freedom of movement throughout the countries (regions) of the state and the choice of occupations for their food and life.
